content: In California, the time it takes to legally change your gender can vary depending on a number of factors such as the court's schedule, the completeness of your application, and whether or not your application is contested. Typically, once you file your petition for change of gender and issuance of a new birth certificate and provide proof of medical treatment, there may be a waiting period of up to six months for the hearing date to be scheduled. During this time, the court may also require additional documentation or information to support your request. After the hearing, the court will issue a court order which can take several weeks to be processed. Once the court order is obtained, you can then present the order to the California Department of Public Health, Vital Records to have your gender marker and name revised on your birth certificate. Therefore, the whole process can take several months or longer depending on how swiftly the court processes the applications and the amount of time it takes for the California Department of Public Health, Vital Records to update the birth certificate.
